page.title: 11TREVELGUE HEAD
page.content: Very little evidence remains to show Trevelgue's true identity. There are two barrows on the island and two more slightly north on the mainland. The other visible remnants are the ramparts. Trevelgue was very heavily defended, traces of 9 are left, but 7 are clearly distinguishable. Unfortunately, public foot-paths criss-cross the ramparts and at these points passageways have been worn through them. No one so far has considered Trevelgue important enough to excavate thoroughly, or to have it protected from human erosion. This kind of attack is slowly but surely destroying the visible remains of Trevelgue. There is also a blow-hole on the headland which is thought to have been an iron mine. Iron deposits can still be found.
